news.title: Word of the Day
news.description:
Operational Costs
Operational costs are the expense that a company incurs for its day-to-day operations.
This includes raw material expenses as well as selling and administrative expenses like rent and employee salaries.
These can be different for different sectors.
For FMCG, raw material costs can be the primary operational expenses, for service-based companies, rent and salaries can be the significant operating costs.

news.title: 6 Day Course
news.description:
Theme: terms used to describe market downs
Day 5: Friday
There are many other terms that are loosely used to describe different types of downs.
Most of them do not have a clear definition — they are casually used by investors and the media.
We’ve spoken of ‘crash’ earlier in this course. Likewise, there are other scarier terms like ‘market rout’, ‘bloodbath’, and a few others.
Newer words are coined on social media every now and then — almost none of them have a clear definition.
Investors must understand that when viewing a stock’s falling price or a market’s falling index, such terms are not of much use.
Investors must also observe the percentage by which the fall has occurred more than anything else and decide for themselves.

news.title: Featured Question
news.description:
"Why SIP in Mutual Funds is being encouraged so often?"
There are many reasons why. Some main reasons are:
-Investing every month. This sounds simple but is a surprisingly big problem. Investors tend to forget or skip investing often. With SIP, the investment automatically happens every month.
Even though the investor can cancel the SIP at any time, many don’t cancel.
-Another reason is that it averages investments going into the mutual fund. When you invest regularly via SIP, on some days, the markets will be high and on some days, it will be low.
Thus, by starting an SIP, an investor reduces the risk of getting into the market at the wrong time with his/her entire investment amount.
